response: "{ \"title\": \"Easy: Counting Mountains\", \"description\": \"You are given a list of integers where each integer represents the height of a mountain. You need to count how many mountains have more than one peak.\\n\\n#### Function Signature\\n```python\\ndef count_mountains(mountains: list[int]) -> int:\\n```\\n\\n#### Input\\n- `mountains` (list[int]): A list of integers where each integer represents the height of a mountain.\\n\\n#### Output\\n- Returns the number of mountains that have more than one peak.\\n\", \"code\": \"def count_mountains(mountains: list[int]) -> int:\\n    count = 0\\n    for i in range(1, len(mountains) - 1):\\n        if (mountains[i] < mountains[i-1] and mountains[i] > mountains[i+1]) or (mountains[i] > mountains[i-1] and mountains[i] < mountains[i+1]):\\n            count += 1\\n    return count\", \"tests\": [\"assert count_mountains([3, 2, 4, 5, 2, 1]) == 2\", \"assert count_mountains([1, 2, 1]) == 0\", \"assert count_mountains([5, 2, 3, 4, 5]) == 1\"] }"
